measured_by: Choice proportions of smaller sooner (SS) or larger later (LL) rewards
justification: The paper discusses the use of choice proportions as a straightforward method to quantify intertemporal choice, exemplified by the equation P(LL) = n(LL) / (n(LL) + n(SS)).

The AUC is described as a method that reflects an individual's overall level of temporal discounting across a range of delays, by computing indifference points and constructing an empirical discounting curve.
The exponential model, used to examine how the subjective value of a larger reward decreases over time, is presented as a fundamental way to quantify temporal discounting.
The hyperbolic model is highlighted for its ability to account for preference reversals and the decreasing rate of discounting as delays increase.

measured_by: Temporal Discounting Drift Diffusion Model (TD DDM)
justification: The TD DDM combines elements of drift diffusion models with temporal discounting to offer a detailed analysis of the decision-making processes involving choices and response times.
